nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3"></script><meta name="next-size-adjust" content=""/><title>Mars landing</title><meta name="description" content="A Mars landing is a landing of a spacecraft on the surface of Mars. Of multiple attempted Mars landings by robotic, uncrewed spacecraft, eleven have had successful soft landings. There have also been studies for a possible human mission to Mars including a landing, but none has been attempted. As of 2025, the Soviet Union, United States, China, and European Space Agency (via the UK-led Beagle 2) have conducted Mars landings successfully.[1][4] Soviet Mars 3, which landed in 1971, was the first..."/><meta name="author" content="system"/><link rel="manifest" href="/manifest.webmanifest"/><meta name="keywords" content="landing on Mars"/><meta name="robots" content="index, follow"/><meta name="googlebot" content="index, follow, max-snippet:-1"/><link rel="canonical" href="https://grokipedia.com/page/Mars_landing"/><meta property="og:title" content="Mars landing"/><meta property="og:description" content="A Mars landing is a landing of a spacecraft on the surface of Mars. Of multiple attempted Mars landings by robotic, uncrewed spacecraft, eleven have had successful soft landings. There have also been studies for a possible human mission to Mars including a landing, but none has been attempted. As of 2025, the Soviet Union, United States, China, and European Space Agency (via the UK-led Beagle 2) have conducted Mars landings successfully.[1][4] Soviet Mars 3, which landed in 1971, was the first..."/><meta property="og:url" content="https://grokipedia.com/page/Mars_landing"/><meta property="og:site_name" content="Grokipedia"/><meta property="og:locale" content="en"/><meta property="og:image" content="https://grokipedia.com/icon-512x512.png"/><meta property="og:image:width" content="512"/><meta property="og:image:height" content="512"/><meta property="og:image:alt" content="Mars landing"/><meta property="og:type" content="article"/><meta property="article:modified_time" content="1970-01-21T09:19:12.986Z"/><meta name="twitter:card" content="summary"/><meta name="twitter:creator" content="@Grokipedia"/><meta name="twitter:title" content="Mars landing"/><meta name="twitter:description" content="A Mars landing is a landing of a spacecraft on the surface of Mars. Of multiple attempted Mars landings by robotic, uncrewed spacecraft, eleven have had successful soft landings. There have also been studies for a possible human mission to Mars including a landing, but none has been attempted. As of 2025, the Soviet Union, United States, China, and European Space Agency (via the UK-led Beagle 2) have conducted Mars landings successfully.[1][4] Soviet Mars 3, which landed in 1971, was the 124.066 820.711 120.595V117.694C820.711 114.223 820.337 111.311 819.59 108.96C818.865 106.609 817.777 104.84 816.327 103.654C814.877 102.445 813.064 101.841 810.889 101.841C808.714 101.841 806.879 102.434 805.385 103.621C803.912 104.785 802.792 106.554 802.023 108.927C801.276 111.278 800.902 114.201 800.902 117.694V120.595C800.902 124.044 801.287 126.945 802.056 129.296C802.825 131.647 803.945 133.416 805.418 134.602C806.89 135.789 808.714 136.382 810.889 136.382ZM838.988 143.205C838 143.205 837.099 142.985 836.286 142.545C835.495 142.106 834.879 141.491 834.44 140.7C834.001 139.909 833.781 class="flex items-center gap-1"><button class="focus-visible:ring-ring inline-flex items-center justify-center gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full text-sm font-medium transition-colors focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 class="inline-flex items-center justify-center p-0 m-0 w-6 h-6 rotate-0 scale-100 transition-all dark:-rotate-90 dark:scale-0" data-namespace="@xai/icons" data-slot="icon"><svg disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary hover:bg-overlay-hover h-9 w-9" type="button"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide h-[calc(100vh-4rem)] w-full transform border-l transition-transform duration-300 ease-in-out sm:w-1/2 md:hidden translate-x-full"><div class="flex flex-col gap-4 p-4"><div class="flex flex-row [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 border-input text-primary data-slot="icon"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" fill="currentColor" viewBox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true" class="w-4 h-4" focusable="false" style="fill:currentColor"><path d="m18.031 16.617 class="text-xs">K</span></div></span></div></button></div></div></div><div><div class="min-[1350px]:grid min-[1350px]:grid-cols-[1fr_3fr_1fr]"><nav class="bg-surface-base hidden h-[calc(100vh-4rem)] overflow-y-auto px-6 pb-32 min-[1350px]:sticky min-[1350px]:top-16 min-[1350px]:block scrollbar-none [-ms-overflow-style:none] [scrollbar-width:none] [&amp;::-webkit-scrollbar]:hidden [overscroll-behavior:contain] pt-8"><ul class="space-y-2 text-sm"><li style="padding-left:0rem" class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 landings</a></li><li style="padding-left:1.5rem" class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 transition-opacity opacity-0"></div><a class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 transition-opacity opacity-0"></div><a href="#mars-express-and-beagle-2" class="transition-opacity hover:opacity-100 opacity-50">Mars Express and Beagle 2</a></li><li style="padding-left:1.5rem" class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 transition-opacity opacity-0"></div><a href="#phoenix" class="transition-opacity hover:opacity-100 Schiaparelli</a></li><li style="padding-left:1.5rem" class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 transition-opacity opacity-0"></div><a href="#insight" class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 transition-opacity opacity-0"></div><a href="#future-missions" class="transition-opacity hover:opacity-100 opacity-50">Future missions</a></li><li style="padding-left:0rem" class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 transition-opacity opacity-0"></div><a opacity-50">Twinned locations to Mars Landing sites on Earth</a></li><li style="padding-left:0.75rem" class="flex items-start gap-2"><div class="bg-foreground mt-[0.5rem] h-1 w-1 flex-shrink-0 transition-opacity opacity-0"></div><a href="#references" class="transition-opacity hover:opacity-100 opacity-50">References</a></li></ul></nav><div class="relative top-16 pb-32 pt-8 px-4 md:px-8"><div class="mx-auto max-w-[850px]"><button data-state="closed" type="button" class="flex items-center"><div class="text-fg-tertiary mb-2 flex cursor-help items-center gap-2 text-sm"><span class="inline-flex items-center justify-center p-0 m-0" data-namespace="@xai/icons" data-slot="icon" style="height:16px;width:16px"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 33 33" aria-hidden="true" class="" focusable="false" style="fill:currentColor;height:16px;width:16px"><path fill="currentColor" d="m13.237 21.04 11.082-8.19c.543-.4 1.32-.244 1.578.38 1.363 3.288.754 7.241-1.957 9.955-2.71 2.714-6.482 3.31-9.93 1.954l-3.765 1.745c5.401 3.697 11.96 2.782 16.059-1.324 3.251-3.255 4.258-7.692 3.317-11.693l.008.009c-1.365-5.878.336-8.227 3.82-13.031q.123-.17.247-.345l-4.585 4.59v-.014L13.234 21.044M10.95 23.031c-3.877-3.707-3.208-9.446.1-12.755 2.446-2.449 6.454-3.448 9.952-1.979L24.76 6.56c-.677-.49-1.545-1.017-2.54-1.387A12.465 12.465 0 0 0 8.675 7.901c-3.519 3.523-4.625 8.94-2.725 13.561 1.42 3.454-.907 5.898-3.251 8.364-.83.874-1.664 1.749-2.335 2.674l10.583-9.466"></path></svg></span><span>Fact-checked by Grok<!-- --> <!-- -->4 days ago</span></div></button><article class="text-[16px]"><h1 id="mars-landing" class="group relative mb-2 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[2.125em] font-semibold tracking-[-1px] [&amp;:not(:first-child)]:mt-14" node="[object Object]">Mars landing<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h1>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">A <strong>Mars landing</strong> is a landing of a <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">spacecraft</span> on the surface of <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars</span>. Of multiple attempted Mars landings by <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">robotic</span>, uncrewed spacecraft, eleven have had successful soft landings. There have also been studies for a possible <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">human mission to Mars</span> including a landing, but none has been attempted.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">As of 2025, the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Soviet Union</span>, <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">United States</span>, <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">China</span>, and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">European Space Agency</span> (via the UK-led Beagle 2) have conducted Mars landings successfully.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_a1abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[1]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_b1abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[2]</sup> Soviet <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 3</span>, which landed in 1971, was the first successful Mars landing, though the spacecraft failed after approximately 15 seconds of transmission on the surface.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_f1abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[3]</sup> All other Soviet Mars landing attempts failed.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_h1abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[3]</sup> <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Viking 1</span> and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Viking 2</span> were the first successful NASA landers, launched in 1975. NASA&#x27;s <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Pathfinder</span>, launched in 1996, successfully delivered the first <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars rover</span>, <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Sojourner</span></em>. In 2021, the first Chinese lander and rover, <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Tianwen 1</span>,<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_v1abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[4]</sup> successfully landed on Mars. The British <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Beagle 2</span> landed in 2003, but due to loss of contact and mission failure, its landing was only confirmed in 2015.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_131abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[2]</sup></span>
<h1 id="methods-of-descent-and-landing" class="group relative mb-2 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[2.125em] font-semibold tracking-[-1px] [&amp;:not(:first-child)]:mt-14" node="[object Object]">Methods of Descent and Landing<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h1>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">As of 2021, all methods of landing on Mars have used an <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">aeroshell</span> and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">parachute</span> sequence for <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars atmospheric entry</span> and descent, but after the parachute is detached, there are three options. A stationary lander can drop from the parachute back shell and ride <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">retrorockets</span> all the way down, but a <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">rover</span> cannot be burdened with rockets that serve no purpose after touchdown.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">One method for lighter rovers is to enclose the rover in a <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">tetrahedral</span> structure which in turn is enclosed in <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">airbags</span>. After the aeroshell drops off, the tetrahedron is lowered clear of the parachute back shell on a tether so that the airbags can inflate. Retrorockets on the back shell can slow descent. When it nears the ground, the tetrahedron is released to drop to the ground, using the airbags as <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">shock absorbers</span>. When it has come to rest, the tetrahedron opens to expose the rover.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_82qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[5]</sup></span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">If a rover is too heavy to use airbags, the retrorockets can be mounted on a <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">sky crane</span>. The sky crane drops from the parachute back shell and, as it nears the ground, the rover is lowered on a tether. When the rover touches ground, it cuts the tether so that the sky crane (with its rockets still firing) will crash well away from the rover. Both <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Curiosity</span></em> and <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Perseverance</span></em> used sky crane for landing.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_83abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[6]</sup></span>
<h2 id="descent-of-heavier-payloads" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.714286em] font-semibold border-border-l1 pb-1 border-b overflow-hidden" node="[object Object]">Descent of heavier payloads<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h2>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The thrusters of the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">InSight</span> lander dug pits during landing beneath it at its landing site.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">For landers that are even heavier than the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Curiosity</em> rover</span> (which required a 4.5 meter (15 feet) diameter aeroshell), engineers tested a combination rigid-inflatable <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Low-Density Supersonic Decelerator</span> in the 2010s that reached 8 meters (26 feet) in diameter. It was designed to be accompanied by a proportionately larger parachute.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_64qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[7]</sup> As of 2025, the technology has not been used in operational Mars missions, with ongoing research exploring alternative entry, descent, and landing systems for heavier payloads, such as those needed for human exploration.</span>
<h2 id="landing-challenges" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.714286em] font-semibold border-border-l1 pb-1 border-b overflow-hidden" node="[object Object]">Landing challenges<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h2>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Landing robotic spacecraft, and possibly some day humans, on Mars is a technological challenge. For a favorable landing, the lander module has to address these issues:<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_25qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[8]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_35qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[9]</sup></span>
<ul class="marker:text-primary my-4 ml-6 list-disc space-y-2 text-[1em]">
<li class="text-[1em]">Thinness of Mars&#x27;s atmosphere</li>
<li class="text-[1em]">Measurement of distance to surface</li>
<li class="text-[1em]">Inadequate technology for ballistic aerocapture</li>
<li class="text-[1em]">Inadequate technology for retropropulsive powered descent</li>
<li class="text-[1em]">Inadequate mission designs</li>
<li class="text-[1em]">Shorter time to perform entry, descent and landing (EDL)</li>
</ul>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">In 2018, NASA successfully landed the InSight lander on the surface of Mars, re-using Viking-era technology.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_26qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[10]</sup> But this technology cannot afford the ability to land large number of cargoes, habitats, ascent vehicles and humans in case of crewed Mars missions in near future. Recent missions like Perseverance (2021) have demonstrated up to 1 tonne landed mass using sky crane and guided entry, paving the way for future supersonic retropropulsion for heavier payloads.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_46qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[11]</sup> In order to improve and accomplish this intent, there is need to upgrade technologies and launch vehicles. Some of the criteria for a lander performing a successful soft-landing based on heritage designs up to the early 2010s are as follows, though recent missions have exceeded several limits:<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_66qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[12]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_76qbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[8]</sup></span>





































<div class="border-border-l1 overflow-x-auto rounded-lg border my-6 w-full"><table node="[object Object]" class="w-full border-collapse text-sm"><thead node="[object Object]" class="border-border-l1 border-b bg-surface-l1"><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><th node="[object Object]" class="dark:text-fg-primary bg-gray-100 px-2 py-1 text-left align-top font-bold dark:bg-black"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Feature</span></th><th node="[object Object]" class="dark:text-fg-primary bg-gray-100 px-2 py-1 text-left align-top font-bold dark:bg-black"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Criterion</span></th></tr></thead><tbody node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-y"><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Mass</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Up to approximately 1 tonne (2,200 lb), as demonstrated by Perseverance (2021)</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Ballistic coefficient</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Typically 60â€“120 kg/mÂ² for successful missions</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Diameter of aeroshell</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Up to 4.5 m (15 ft), as in MSL and Perseverance</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Geometry of aeroshell</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">70Â° spherical cone shell</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Diameter of parachute</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Up to 21.5 m (70 ft), as in Perseverance</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Descent</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Subsonic retropropulsive powered descent (e.g., sky crane)</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Entry</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Direct hyperbolic entry (from interplanetary trajectory)</span></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<h1 id="communicating-with-earth" class="group relative mb-2 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[2.125em] font-semibold tracking-[-1px] [&amp;:not(:first-child)]:mt-14" node="[object Object]">Communicating with Earth<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h1>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Since the first successful soft landing by the Soviet Mars 3 mission in 1971, all landers on the surface of Mars that have communicated with Earth have used orbiting spacecraft as <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">communications satellites</span> for relaying their data to Earth.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_48abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[13]</sup> The landers use <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">UHF</span> transmitters to send their data to the orbiters, which then relay the data to Earth using either <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">X band</span> or <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Ka band</span> frequencies. These higher frequencies, along with more powerful transmitters and larger <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">parabolic reflectors</span>, permit the orbiters to send the data much faster than the landers could manage transmitting directly to Earth, which conserves valuable time on the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">receiving antennas</span>.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_g8abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[14]</sup></span>
<h1 id="list-of-mars-landings" class="group relative mb-2 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[2.125em] font-semibold tracking-[-1px] [&amp;:not(:first-child)]:mt-14" node="[object Object]">List of Mars landings<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h1>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">In the 1970s, several USSR probes unsuccessfully tried to land on Mars. <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 3</span> landed successfully in 1971 but failed soon afterwards. But the American <em>Viking</em> landers made it to the surface and provided several years of images and data. However, the next successful Mars landing was not until 1997, when <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Pathfinder</span> landed.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_89abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[15]</sup> In the 21st century there have been several successful landings, but there have also been many crashes.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_a9abav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[15]</sup></span>
<h3 id="mars-probe-program" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Mars probe program<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The first probe intended to be a Mars <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">impact</span> lander was the Soviet <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 1962B</span></em> , unsuccessfully launched in 1962.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_6aabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[16]</sup></span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">In 1970 the Soviet Union began the design of <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 4NM</span></em> and <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 5NM</span></em> missions with super-heavy uncrewed Martian spacecraft. First was <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Marsokhod</span></em> , with a planned date of early 1973, and second was the Mars sample return mission planned for 1975. Both spacecraft were intended to be launched on the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>N1</em> rocket</span>, but this rocket never flew successfully and the Mars 4NM and Mars 5NM projects were cancelled.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_aaqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[17]</sup></span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">In 1971 the Soviet Union sent probes <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 2</span></em> and <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 3</span></em> , each carrying a lander, as part of the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars probe program</span> M-71. The Mars 2 lander failed to land and impacted Mars. The Mars 3 lander became the first probe to successfully <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">soft-land</span> on Mars, but its data-gathering had less success. The lander began transmitting to the Mars 3 orbiter 90 seconds after landing, but after 14.5 seconds, transmission ceased for unknown reasons. The cause of the failure may have been related to the extremely powerful Martian dust storm taking place at the time. These space probes each contained a Mars rover, <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">PrOP-M</span>, although they were never deployed.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">In 1973, the Soviet Union sent two more landers to Mars, <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 6</span></em> and <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 7</span></em>. The Mars 6 lander transmitted data during descent but failed upon impact. The Mars 7 probe separated prematurely from the carrying vehicle due to a problem in the operation of one of the onboard systems (<span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">attitude control</span> or retro-rockets) and missed the planet by 1,300 km (810 mi).</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The double-launching <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Mars 5M</em> (Mars-79)</span> sample return mission was planned for 1979, but was cancelled due to complexity and technical problems.</span>
<h3 id="viking-program" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Viking program<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">In 1976 two American <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Viking</em> probes</span> entered orbit about Mars and each released a <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">lander module</span> that made a successful <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">soft landing</span> on the planet&#x27;s surface. They subsequently had the first successful transmission of large volumes of data, including the first color pictures and extensive scientific information. Measured temperatures at the landing sites ranged from 150 to 250 K (âˆ’123 to âˆ’23 Â°C; âˆ’190 to âˆ’10 Â°F), with a variation over a given day of 35 to 50 Â°C (95 to 122 Â°F). Seasonal dust storms, pressure changes, and movement of atmospheric gases between the polar caps were observed. A <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">biology experiment</span> produced possible evidence of life, but it was not corroborated by other on-board experiments.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">While searching for a suitable landing spot for <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Viking 2</span></em> &#x27;s lander, the <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Viking 1</span></em> orbiter photographed the landform that constitutes the so-called &quot;<span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Face on Mars</span>&quot; on 25 July 1976.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The Viking program was a descendant of the cancelled <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Voyager program</span>, whose name was later reused for a pair of outer solar system probes.</span>
<h3 id="mars-pathfinder" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]"><em>Mars Pathfinder</em><button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7"><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">NASA</span>&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Pathfinder</span></em> spacecraft, with assistance from the <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Global Surveyor</span></em> orbiter, landed on 4 July 1997. Its landing site was an ancient flood plain in Mars&#x27;s northern hemisphere called <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Ares Vallis</span>, which is among the rockiest parts of Mars. It carried a tiny remote-controlled rover called <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Sojourner</em></span>, the first successful <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars rover</span>, that traveled a few meters around the landing site, exploring the conditions and sampling rocks around it. Newspapers around the world carried images of the lander dispatching the rover to explore the surface of Mars in a way never achieved before.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Until the final data transmission on 27 September 1997, <em>Mars Pathfinder</em> returned 16,500 images from the lander and 550 images from the rover, as well as more than 15 chemical analyses of rocks and soil and extensive data on winds and other weather factors. Findings from the investigations carried out by scientific instruments on both the lander and the rover suggest that in the past Mars has been warm and wet, with liquid water and a thicker atmosphere. The mission website was the most heavily trafficked up to that time.</span>
<h3 id="spate-of-failures" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Spate of failures<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>




























































<div class="border-border-l1 overflow-x-auto rounded-lg border my-6 w-full"><table node="[object Object]" class="w-full border-collapse text-sm"><thead node="[object Object]" class="border-border-l1 border-b bg-surface-l1"><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><th node="[object Object]" class="dark:text-fg-primary bg-gray-100 px-2 py-1 text-left align-top font-bold dark:bg-black"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Spacecraft 1988â€“1999</span></th><th node="[object Object]" class="dark:text-fg-primary bg-gray-100 px-2 py-1 text-left align-top font-bold dark:bg-black"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Evaluation</span></th><th node="[object Object]" class="dark:text-fg-primary bg-gray-100 px-2 py-1 text-left align-top font-bold dark:bg-black"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Had or was Lander</span></th></tr></thead><tbody node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-y"><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Phobos 1</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">For Phobos</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Phobos 2</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Yes</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">For Phobos</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Observer</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 96</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Yes</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><em>Mars Pathfinder</em></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Yes</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Yes</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Global Surveyor</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Yes</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Climate Orbiter</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Polar Lander</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Yes</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Deep Space 2</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Yes</span></td></tr><tr node="[object Object]" class="divide-border-l1 divide-x bg-surface-l1"><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">Nozomi</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td><td node="[object Object]" class="text-fg-primary px-2 py-1 align-top"><span class="text-[1em] leading-7">No</span></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7"><em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 96</span></em> , an orbiter launched on 16 November 1996 by Russia, failed when the planned second burn of the Block D-2 fourth stage did not occur. Following the success of Global Surveyor and Pathfinder, another spate of failures occurred in 1998 and 1999, with the Japanese <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Nozomi</em></span> orbiter and NASA&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Climate Orbiter</span></em> , <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Polar Lander</span></em> , and <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Deep Space 2</span></em> penetrators all suffering various terminal errors. Mars Climate Orbiter is infamous for <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Lockheed Martin</span> engineers mixing up the usage of <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">U.S. customary units</span> with <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">metric units</span>, causing the orbiter to burn up while entering Mars&#x27;s atmosphere. Out of 5â€“6 NASA missions in the 1990s, only 2 worked: Mars Pathfinder and Mars Global Surveyor, making Mars Pathfinder and its rover the only successful Mars landing in the 1990s.</span>
<h3 id="mars-express-and-beagle-2" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Mars Express and <em>Beagle 2</em><button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">On 2 June 2003, the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">European Space Agency</span>&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Express</span></em> set off from <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Baikonur Cosmodrome</span> to Mars. The Mars Express craft consisted of the <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Express Orbiter</span></em> and the lander <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Beagle 2</span></em>. Although the landing probe was not designed to move, it carried a digging device and the least massive spectrometer created to date, as well as a range of other devices, on a robotic arm in order to accurately analyse soil beneath the dusty surface.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The orbiter entered Mars orbit on 25 December 2003, and <em>Beagle 2</em> should have entered Mars&#x27;s atmosphere the same day. However, attempts to contact the lander failed. Communications attempts continued throughout January, but <em>Beagle 2</em> was declared lost in mid-February, and a joint inquiry was launched by the UK and ESA that blamed principal investigator <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Colin Pillinger</span>&#x27;s poor project management. Nevertheless, Mars Express Orbiter confirmed the presence of water ice and carbon dioxide ice at the planet&#x27;s south pole. NASA had previously confirmed their presence at the north pole of Mars.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Signs of the <em>Beagle 2</em> lander were found in 2013 by the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">HiRISE</span> camera on NASA&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter</span></em> , and the <em>Beagle 2</em> &#x27;s presence was confirmed in January 2015, several months after Pillinger&#x27;s death. The lander appears to have successfully landed but not deployed all of its power and communications panels.</span>
<h3 id="mars-exploration-rovers" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Mars Exploration Rovers<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Shortly after the launch of Mars Express, NASA sent a pair of twin rovers toward the planet as part of the <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Exploration Rover</span></em> mission. On 10 June 2003, NASA&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">MER-A</span></em> <em>(Spirit)</em> Mars Exploration Rover was launched. It successfully landed in <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Gusev Crater</span> (believed once to have been a crater lake) on 3 January 2004. It examined rock and soil for evidence of the area&#x27;s history of water. On 7 July 2003, a second rover, <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">MER-B</span></em> <em>(Opportunity)</em> was launched. It landed on 24 January 2004 in <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Meridiani Planum</span> (where there are large deposits of <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">hematite</span>, indicating the presence of past water) to carry out similar geological work.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Despite a temporary loss of communication with the <em>Spirit</em> rover (caused by a file system anomaly<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_4kqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[18]</sup>) delaying exploration for several days, both rovers eventually began exploring their landing sites. The rover <em>Opportunity</em> landed in a particularly interesting spot, a crater with bedrock outcroppings. In fast succession, mission team members announced on 2 March that data returned from the rover showed that these rocks were once &quot;drenched in water&quot;, and on 23 March that it was concluded that they were laid down underwater in a salty sea. This represented the first strong direct evidence for liquid water on Mars at some time in the past.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Towards the end of July 2005, it was reported by the <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Sunday Times</span></em> that the rovers may have carried the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">bacteria</span> <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Bacillus safensis</span></em> to Mars. According to one NASA microbiologist, this bacteria could survive both the trip and conditions on Mars. Despite efforts to sterilise both landers, neither could be assured to be completely sterile.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_8labav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[19]</sup></span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Having been designed for only three-month missions, both rovers lasted much longer than planned. <em>Spirit</em> lost contact with Earth in March 2010, 74 months after commencing exploration. <em>Opportunity</em> , however, continued to carry out surveys of the planet, surpassing 45 km (28 mi) on its odometer by the time communication with it was lost in June 2018, 173 months after it began.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_6lqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[20]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_7lqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[21]</sup> These rovers have discovered many new things, including <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Heat Shield Rock</span>, the first <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">meteorite</span> to be discovered on another planet.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Here is some debris from a Mars landing, as viewed by a Rover. This shows the area around a heat shield and resulting shield impact crater. The heat shield was jettisoned during the descent, impacting the surface on its own trajectory, while the spacecraft went on to land the rover.</span>
<h3 id="phoenix" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]"><em>Phoenix</em><button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7"><em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Phoenix</span></em> launched on 4 August 2007, and touched down on the northern polar region of Mars on 25 May 2008. It is famous for having been successfully photographed while landing, since this was the first time one spacecraft captured the landing of another spacecraft onto a planet.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_3nabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[22]</sup></span>
<h3 id="mars-science-laboratory" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Mars Science Laboratory<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Science Laboratory (MSL)</span> (and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Curiosity rover</span>), launched in November 2011, landed in a location that is now called &quot;<span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Bradbury Landing</span>&quot;, on <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Aeolis Palus</span>, between <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Peace Vallis</span> and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Aeolis Mons (&quot;Mount Sharp&quot;)</span>, in <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Gale Crater</span> on <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars</span> on 6 August 2012, 05:17 UTC.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_ioabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[23]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_joabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[24]</sup> The landing site was in <em>Quad 51</em> (&quot;Yellowknife&quot;)<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_noabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[25]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_ooabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[26]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_poabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[27]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_qoabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[28]</sup> of <em>Aeolis Palus</em> near the base of <em>Aeolis Mons</em>. The landing site<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_10oabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[29]</sup> was less than 2.4 km (1.5 mi) from the center of the rover&#x27;s planned target site after a 563,000,000 km (350,000,000 mi) journey.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_12oabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[30]</sup> <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">NASA</span> named the landing site &quot;<span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Bradbury Landing</span>&quot;, in honor of author <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Ray Bradbury</span>, on 22 August 2012.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_1aoabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[29]</sup></span>
<h3 id="exomars-schiaparelli" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">ExoMars <em>Schiaparelli</em><button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Schiaparelli</em> lander</span> was intended to test technology for future soft landings on the surface of Mars as part of the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">ExoMars</span> project. It was built in <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Italy</span> by the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">European Space Agency</span> (ESA) and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Roscosmos</span>. It was launched together with the <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter</span> (TGO) on 14 March 2016 and attempted a landing on 19 October 2016. Telemetry was lost about one minute before the scheduled landing time,<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_epabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[31]</sup> but confirmed that most elements of the landing plan, including heat shield operation, parachute deployment, and rocket activation, had been successful.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_gpabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[32]</sup> The <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter</span> later captured imagery showing what appears to be Schiaparelli&#x27;s crash site.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_kpabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[33]</sup></span>
<h3 id="insight" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]"><em>InSight</em><button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">NASA&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">InSight</span></em> lander <em>,</em> designed to study seismology and heat flow from the deep interior of Mars, was launched on 5 May 2018. It landed successfully in Mars&#x27;s <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Elysium Planitia</span> on 26 November 2018.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_8qabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[34]</sup></span>
<h3 id="mars-2020-and-tianwen-1" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Mars 2020 and <em>Tianwen-1</em><button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">NASA&#x27;s <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars 2020</span> and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">CNSA</span>&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Tianwen-1</span></em> were both launched in the July 2020 window. Mars 2020&#x27;s rover <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Perseverance</em></span> successfully landed, in a location that is now called &quot;<span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Octavia E. Butler Landing</span>&quot;, in <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Jezero Crater</span> on 18 February 2021,<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_erabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[35]</sup> <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Ingenuity</em> helicopter</span> was deployed and took subsequent flights in April.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_irabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[36]</sup> <em>Tianwen</em> -1&#x27;s lander and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7"><em>Zhurong</em></span> rover landed in <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Utopia Planitia</span> on 14 May 2021 with the rover being deployed on 22 May 2021 and dropping a remote selfie camera on 1 June 2021.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_qrabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[37]</sup></span>
<h3 id="future-missions" class="group relative mb-2 mt-7 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[1.428571em] font-semibold" node="[object Object]">Future missions<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h3>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">ESA</span>&#x27;s <em><span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Rosalind Franklin</span></em> rover is planned for launch in 2028 with a new European lander developed by Airbus and would obtain soil samples from up to 2 metres (6 ft 7 in) depth and make an extensive search for <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">biosignatures</span> and <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">biomolecules</span>. There is an ongoing <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Mars Sample Return Mission</span> by ESA and NASA, with sample return projected for 2035â€“2039 following redesigns announced in 2025.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_csabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[38]</sup> This mission would be part of the European <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Aurora Programme</span>.</span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">The <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Indian Space Research Organisation</span> (ISRO)&#x27;s Mangalyaan-2 mission, approved in 2025, plans to land a rover and rotorcraft/helicopter around 2031.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_4sqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[39]</sup> China plans the Tianwen-3 sample-return mission for launch around 2028, including a landing and ascent vehicle.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_6sqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[40]</sup></span>
<h1 id="landing-site-identification" class="group relative mb-2 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[2.125em] font-semibold tracking-[-1px] [&amp;:not(:first-child)]:mt-14" node="[object Object]">Landing site identification<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h1>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Landing site identification for Mars missions involves two primary phases: pre-mission selection based on orbital data and real-time hazard detection and avoidance during entry, descent, and landing (EDL).
