These processes ensure safe touchdowns in challenging terrain while prioritizing scientific objectives.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_2tqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[41]</sup></span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">Pre-mission site selection begins years before launch, using high-resolution imagery and topographic data from orbiters such as NASA&#x27;s Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO). Candidate sites are evaluated for engineering constraints, including low elevation (to allow thicker atmosphere for aerobraking), latitudes between 5Â°N and 5Â°S for sufficient solar power, slopes less than 15 degrees, and few rocks larger than 0.5 meters to avoid damaging the lander or rover. Sites are also chosen for scientific value, such as evidence of past water or habitability. For example, the Perseverance rover&#x27;s Jezero Crater site was selected in 2017 after workshops evaluating multiple candidates.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_2uabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[42]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_3uabav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[43]</sup></span>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">During descent, advanced missions employ autonomous systems to identify and avoid hazards in real time. Early landers like Viking relied on pre-selected &quot;go/no-go&quot; zones without onboard imaging. However, since the 2010s, technologies like the Hazard Detection and Avoidance (HDA) system have been developed. NASA&#x27;s Perseverance mission (landed February 2021) used Terrain-Relative Navigation (TRN), which compares descent images from onboard cameras to onboard maps derived from MRO data, enabling precise landing within 100 meters of the target and avoiding slopes or boulders. China&#x27;s Tianwen-1 mission (landed May 2021) also incorporated similar autonomous capabilities for its Zhurong rover in Utopia Planitia. As of October 2025, no additional soft landings have occurred, but future missions like NASA&#x27;s Mars Sample Return plan to leverage enhanced precision landing technologies.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_2uqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[44]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_3uqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[45]</sup></span>
<h1 id="twinned-locations-to-mars-landing-sites-on-earth" class="group relative mb-2 scroll-mt-24 font-serif text-[2.125em] font-semibold tracking-[-1px] [&amp;:not(:first-child)]:mt-14" node="[object Object]">Twinned locations to Mars Landing sites on Earth<button class="focus-visible:ring-ring gap-x-2 whitespace-nowrap rounded-full font-medium focus-visible:outline-none focus-visible:ring-1 disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:cursor-not-allowed disabled:opacity-50 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:-mx-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:my-0.5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:size-5 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:shrink-0 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:text-[--btn-icon] [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:my-1 [&amp;&gt;[data-slot=icon]]:sm:size-4 text-primary text-xs ml-2 inline-flex h-6 w-6 items-center justify-center p-0 align-middle opacity-0 transition-opacity hover:bg-gray-100 dark:hover:bg-gray-800" type="button" aria-label="Copy link to heading" data-state="closed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide lucide-link h-4 w-4"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></button></h1>
<span class="mb-4 block break-words text-[1em] leading-7">In the run-up to NASAâ€™s Mars 2020 landing, former planetary scientist and film-maker <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Christopher Riley</span> mapped the locations of all eight of NASA&#x27;s successful Mars landing sites onto their equivalent spots on Earth, in terms of latitudes and longitudes; presenting pairs of photographs from each twinned interplanetary location on Earth and Mars to draw attention to climate change.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_4vqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[46]</sup> Following the successful landing of NASA&#x27;s <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Perseverance Rover</span> on February 18, 2021, Riley called for volunteers to travel to and photograph its twinned Earth location in Andegaon Wadi, Sawali, in the central Indian state of <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Maharashtra</span> (18.445Â°N, 77.451Â°E).<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_avqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[47]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_bvqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[48]</sup><sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_cvqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[49]</sup> Eventually <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">BBC World Service</span> radio programme <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Digital Planet</span> listener Gowri Abhiram, from <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Hyderabad</span> took up the challenge, and travelled there on the 22nd January 2022, becoming the first person to knowingly reach a spot on Earth that matches the latitude and longitude of a robotic presence on the surface of another world.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_kvqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[50]</sup> China&#x27;s Tianwen-1 landing site maps onto an area in Southern China, 40 kilometres Southwest of <span class="inline text-[1em] leading-7">Guilin</span> and is yet to be photographed for the project.<sup class="text-fg-secondary ml-[2px] cursor-pointer text-xs hover:underline" type="button" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="radix-_R_ovqbav9fiumdb_" data-state="closed" tabindex="-1" style="outline:none">[48]</sup></span></article><div id="references" class="min-w-0 scroll-mt-8 nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"1:\"$Sreact.fragment\"\n3:I[91363,[],\"\"]\n4:I[23775,[],\"\"]\n5:I[57654,[\"8739\",\"static/chunks/63f0ec43-8ee6a76d70472249.js\",\"7670\",\"static/chunks/7670-7326298c9856172b.js\",\"282\",\"static/chunks/282-691fffb366e24ca5.js\",\"7515\",\"static/chunks/7515-336759ef5dad2b52.js\",\"927\",\"static/chunks/927-34e2a6da3e15e26b.js\",\"5855\",\"static/chunks/5855-243eeca8f0e4cabd.js\",\"4393\",\"static/chunks/4393-1c8dff25ec904469.js\",\"2225\",\"static/chunks/2225-454cf9f44775e7ce.js\",\"7618\",\"static/chunks/7618-43536a8fb0dd3bfe.js\",\"3699\",\"static/chunks/app/page/%5Bslug%5D/layout-55a344716dd57c44.js\"],\"PageHeaderProvider\"]\n6:I[17618,[\"8739\",\"static/chunks/63f0ec43-8ee6a76d70472249.js\",\"7670\",\"static/chunks/7670-7326298c9856172b.js\",\"282\",\"static/chunks/282-691fffb366e24ca5.js\",\"7515\",\"static/chunks/7515-336759ef5dad2b52.js\",\"927\",\"static/chunks/927-34e2a6da3e15e26b.js\",\"5855\",\"static/chunks/5855-243eeca8f0e4cabd.js\",\"4393\",\"static/chunks/4393-1c8dff25ec904469.js\",\"2225\",\"static/chunks/2225-454cf9f44775e7ce.js\",\"7618\",\"static/chunks/7618-43536a8fb0dd3bfe.js\",\"3699\",\"static/chunks/app/page/%5Bslug%5D/layout-55a344716dd57c44.js\"],\"HeaderContent\"]\n7:I[25529,[\"8739\",\"static/chunks/63f0ec43-8ee6a76d70472249.js\",\"7670\",\"static/chunks/7670-7326298c9856172b.js\",\"282\",\"static/chunks/282-691fffb366e24ca5.js\",\"7515\",\"static/chunks/7515-336759ef5dad2b52.js\",\"927\",\"static/chunks/927-34e2a6da3e15e26b.js\",\"7720\",\"static/chunks/7720-3a1e7e411adba2d3.js\",\"7086\",\"static/chunks/7086-1f1c4891d766e04f.js\",\"5855\",\"static/chunks/5855-243eeca8f0e4cabd.js\",\"4393\",\"static/chunks/4393-1c8dff25ec904469.js\",\"2225\",\"static/chunks/2225-454cf9f44775e7ce.js\",\"7618\",\"static/chunks/7618-43536a8fb0dd3bfe.js\",\"6751\",\"static/chunks/app/page/%5Bslug%5D/not-found-69a3edc7db5749d6.js\"],\"default\"]\n9:I[6666,[],\"OutletBoundary\"]\nb:I[80415,[],\"AsyncMetadataOutlet\"]\nd:I[6666,[],\"ViewportBoundary\"]\nf:I[6666,[],\"MetadataBoundary\"]\n10:\"$Sreact.suspense\"\n12:I[95909,[\"4219\",\"static/chunks/app/global-error-4d07d20223cd4b4c.js\"],\"default\"]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/1f2316909698f815.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossO"])</script><script nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"rigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/3d4419af2cf8609b.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossOrigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/4dec29efcaeb336c.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossOrigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/74452ea3ef0f9101.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossOrigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/904ef0a86fe32a00.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossOrigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/d886a03bcda7ad8f.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossOrigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/e1447589d6f59c4b.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossOrigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/media/f5a90156f8995c8c.p.woff2\",\"font\",{\"crossOrigin\":\"\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\",\"type\":\"font/woff2\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/css/62c4caba71dfda84.css\",\"style\",{\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/css/eb3d87f98fe1565f.css\",\"style\",{\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/css/1b5e561215938d4d.css\",\"style\",{\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/css/0227d069a630d414.css\",\"style\",{\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}]\n:HL[\"/_next/static/css/f87fff2ab93d05a7.css\",\"style\",{\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"0:{\"P\":null,\"b\":\"BpM29AX4fmgcUxZ_6t0le\",\"p\":\"\",\"c\":[\"\",\"page\",\"Mars_landing\"],\"i\":false,\"f\":[[[\"\",{\"children\":[\"page\",{\"children\":[[\"slug\",\"Mars_landing\",\"d\"],{\"children\":[\"__PAGE__\",{}]}]}]},\"$undefined\",\"$undefined\",true],[\"\",[\"$\",\"$1\",\"c\",{\"children\":[[[\"$\",\"link\",\"0\",{\"rel\":\"stylesheet\",\"href\":\"/_next/static/css/62c4caba71dfda84.css\",\"precedence\":\"next\",\"crossOrigin\":\"$undefined\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}],[\"$\",\"link\",\"1\",{\"rel\":\"stylesheet\",\"href\":\"/_next/static/css/eb3d87f98fe1565f.css\",\"precedence\":\"next\",\"crossOrigin\":\"$undefined\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}],[\"$\",\"link\",\"2\",{\"rel\":\"stylesheet\",\"href\":\"/_next/static/css/1b5e561215938d4d.css\",\"precedence\":\"next\",\"crossOrigin\":\"$undefined\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}],[\"$\",\"link\",\"3\",{\"rel\":\"stylesheet\",\"href\":\"/_next/static/css/0227d069a630d414.css\",\"precedence\":\"next\",\"crossOrigin\":\"$undefined\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}]],\"$L2\"]}],{\"children\":[\"page\",[\"$\",\"$1\",\"c\",{\"children\":[null,[\"$\",\"$L3\",null,{\"parallelRouterKey\":\"children\",\"error\":\"$undefined\",\"errorStyles\":\"$undefined\",\"errorScripts\":\"$undefined\",\"template\":[\"$\",\"$L4\",null,{}],\"templateStyles\":\"$undefined\",\"templateScripts\":\"$undefined\",\"notFound\":\"$undefined\",\"forbidden\":\"$undefined\",\"unauthorized\":\"$undefined\"}]]}],{\"children\":[[\"slug\",\"Mars_landing\",\"d\"],[\"$\",\"$1\",\"c\",{\"children\":[null,[\"$\",\"$L5\",null,{\"children\":[[\"$\",\"$L6\",null,{\"maxWidth\":\"full\",\"mobileOptions\":{\"right\":{\"showFixedIssues\":true,\"showThemeSwitcher\":true,\"showSearch\":true,\"showTableOfContents\":true}}}],[\"$\",\"$L3\",null,{\"parallelRouterKey\":\"children\",\"error\":\"$undefined\",\"errorStyles\":\"$undefined\",\"errorScripts\":\"$undefined\",\"template\":[\"$\",\"$L4\",null,{}],\"templateStyles\":\"$undefined\",\"templateScripts\":\"$undefined\",\"notFound\":[[\"$\",\"$L7\",null,{}],[]],\"forbidden\":\"$undefined\",\"unauthorized\":\"$undefined\"}]]}]]}],{\"children\":[\"__PAGE__\",[\"$\",\"$1\",\"c\",{\"children\":[\"$L8\",[[\"$\",\"link\",\"0\",{\"rel\":\"stylesheet\",\"href\":\"/_next/static/css/f87fff2ab93d05a7.css\",\"precedence\":\"next\",\"crossOrigin\":\"$undefined\",\"nonce\":\"NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3\"}]],[\"$\",\"$L9\",null,{\"children\":[\"$La\",[\"$\",\"$Lb\",null,{\"promise\":\"$@c\"}]]}]]}],{},null,false]},null,false]},null,false]},null,false],[\"$\",\"$1\",\"h\",{\"children\":[null,[[\"$\",\"$Ld\",null,{\"children\":\"$Le\"}],[\"$\",\"meta\",null,{\"name\":\"next-size-adjust\",\"content\":\"\"}]],[\"$\",\"$Lf\",null,{\"children\":[\"$\",\"div\",null,{\"hidden\":true,\"children\":[\"$\",\"$10\",null,{\"fallback\":null,\"children\":\"$L11\"}]}]}]]}],false]],\"m\":\"$undefined\",\"G\":[\"$12\",[]],\"s\":false,\"S\":false}\n"])</script><script nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"e:[[\"$\",\"meta\",\"0\",{\"charSet\":\"utf-8\"}],[\"$\",\"meta\",\"1\",{\"name\":\"viewport\",\"content\":\"width=device-width, initial-scale=1, interactive-widget=resizes-content\"}]]\na:null\n"])</script><script nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"13:I[42712,[\"8739\",\"static/chunks/63f0ec43-8ee6a76d70472249.js\",\"2254\",\"static/chunks/8208b75a-a48e5a4507a0de91.js\",\"4684\",\"static/chunks/24cf1b50-159cca90b09285e0.js\",\"1829\",\"static/chunks/9ffa21ba-c069766d809bd4c7.js\",\"7670\",\"static/chunks/7670-7326298c9856172b.js\",\"282\",\"static/chunks/282-691fffb366e24ca5.js\",\"7515\",\"static/chunks/7515-336759ef5dad2b52.js\",\"5497\",\"static/chunks/5497-ab85ef3ea59dd353.js\",\"7720\",\"static/chunks/7720-3a1e7e411adba2d3.js\",\"6281\",\"static/chunks/6281-c6e84786dade3614.js\",\"7086\",\"static/chunks/7086-1f1c4891d766e04f.js\",\"600\",\"static/chunks/600-9a9fcafaaa6c1c4c.js\",\"5002\",\"static/chunks/5002-9735c25beda556ba.js\",\"5448\",\"static/chunks/5448-2a3cfd853d899c9a.js\",\"5855\",\"static/chunks/5855-243eeca8f0e4cabd.js\",\"4393\",\"static/chunks/4393-1c8dff25ec904469.js\",\"9214\",\"static/chunks/9214-a10614844a67ba31.js\",\"8\",\"static/chunks/8-8ca70ca619d8e099.js\",\"4789\",\"static/chunks/4789-2080f6497f78b5b6.js\",\"6304\",\"static/chunks/app/page/%5Bslug%5D/page-540a27b6839afde5.js\"],\"HydrationBoundary\"]\n"])</script><script nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"16:I[6367,[],\"IconMark\"]\n14:T6d66,"])</script><script nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"# Mars landing\n\nA **Mars landing** is a landing of a [spacecraft](Spacecraft \"Spacecraft\") on the surface of [Mars](Mars \"Mars\"). Of multiple attempted Mars landings by [robotic](Robotic_spacecraft \"Robotic spacecraft\"), uncrewed spacecraft, eleven have had successful soft landings. There have also been studies for a possible [human mission to Mars](Human_mission_to_Mars \"Human mission to Mars\") including a landing, but none has been attempted. \n\nAs of 2025, the [Soviet Union](Soviet_Union \"Soviet Union\"), [United States](United_States \"United States\"), [China](China \"China\"), and [European Space Agency](European_Space_Agency \"European Space Agency\") (via the UK-led Beagle 2) have conducted Mars landings successfully.[1][4] Soviet [Mars 3](Mars_3 \"Mars 3\"), which landed in 1971, was the first successful Mars landing, though the spacecraft failed after approximately 15 seconds of transmission on the surface.[2] All other Soviet Mars landing attempts failed.[2] [Viking 1](Viking_1 \"Viking 1\") and [Viking 2](Viking_2 \"Viking 2\") were the first successful NASA landers, launched in 1975. NASA's [Mars Pathfinder](Mars_Pathfinder \"Mars Pathfinder\"), launched in 1996, successfully delivered the first [Mars rover](Mars_rover \"Mars rover\"), _[Sojourner](Sojourner_\\(rover\\) \"Sojourner \\(rover\\)\")_. In 2021, the first Chinese lander and rover, [Tianwen 1](Tianwen_1 \"Tianwen 1\"),[3] successfully landed on Mars. The British [Beagle 2](Beagle_2 \"Beagle 2\") landed in 2003, but due to loss of contact and mission failure, its landing was only confirmed in 2015.[4]\n# Methods of Descent and Landing\n\nAs of 2021, all methods of landing on Mars have used an [aeroshell](Aeroshell \"Aeroshell\") and [parachute](Parachute \"Parachute\") sequence for [Mars atmospheric entry](Mars_atmospheric_entry \"Mars atmospheric entry\") and descent, but after the parachute is detached, there are three options. A stationary lander can drop from the parachute back shell and ride [retrorockets](Retrorocket \"Retrorocket\") all the way down, but a [rover](Rover_\\(space_exploration\\) \"Rover \\(space exploration\\)\") cannot be burdened with rockets that serve no purpose after touchdown. \n\nOne method for lighter rovers is to enclose the rover in a [tetrahedral](Tetrahedron \"Tetrahedron\") structure which in turn is enclosed in [airbags](Airbag \"Airbag\"). After the aeroshell drops off, the tetrahedron is lowered clear of the parachute back shell on a tether so that the airbags can inflate. Retrorockets on the back shell can slow descent. When it nears the ground, the tetrahedron is released to drop to the ground, using the airbags as [shock absorbers](Shock_absorber \"Shock absorber\"). When it has come to rest, the tetrahedron opens to expose the rover.[5]\n\nIf a rover is too heavy to use airbags, the retrorockets can be mounted on a [sky crane](Sky_crane_\\(landing_system\\) \"Sky crane \\(landing system\\)\"). The sky crane drops from the parachute back shell and, as it nears the ground, the rover is lowered on a tether. When the rover touches ground, it cuts the tether so that the sky crane (with its rockets still firing) will crash well away from the rover. Both _[Curiosity](Curiosity_\\(rover\\) \"Curiosity \\(rover\\)\")_ and _[Perseverance](Perseverance_\\(rover\\) \"Perseverance \\(rover\\)\")_ used sky crane for landing.[6]\n## Descent of heavier payloads\n\nThe thrusters of the [InSight](InSight \"InSight\") lander dug pits during landing beneath it at its landing site.\n\nFor landers that are even heavier than the [_Curiosity_ rover](Curiosity_rover \"Curiosity rover\") (which required a 4.5 meter (15 feet) diameter aeroshell), engineers tested a combination rigid-inflatable [Low-Density Supersonic Decelerator](Low-Density_Supersonic_Decelerator \"Low-Density Supersonic Decelerator\") in the 2010s that reached 8 meters (26 feet) in diameter. It was designed to be accompanied by a proportionately larger parachute.[7] As of 2025, the technology has not been used in operational Mars missions, with ongoing research exploring alternative entry, descent, and landing systems for heavier payloads, such as those needed for human exploration.\n## Landing challenges\n\nLanding robotic spacecraft, and possibly some day humans, on Mars is a technological challenge. For a favorable landing, the lander module has to address these issues:[8][9]\n\n* Thinness of Mars's atmosphere\n* Measurement of distance to surface\n* Inadequate technology for ballistic aerocapture\n* Inadequate technology for retropropulsive powered descent\n* Inadequate mission designs\n* Shorter time to perform entry, descent and landing (EDL)\n\nIn 2018, NASA successfully landed the InSight lander on the surface of Mars, re-using Viking-era technology.[10] But this technology cannot afford the ability to land large number of cargoes, habitats, ascent vehicles and humans in case of crewed Mars missions in near future. Recent missions like Perseverance (2021) have demonstrated up to 1 tonne landed mass using sky crane and guided entry, paving the way for future supersonic retropropulsion for heavier payloads.[](https://www.nasa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/iparch12-wp-mars-edl.pdf?emrc=82c2a9) In order to improve and accomplish this intent, there is need to upgrade technologies and launch vehicles. Some of the criteria for a lander performing a successful soft-landing based on heritage designs up to the early 2010s are as follows, though recent missions have exceeded several limits:[11][8]\n\n| Feature                  | Criterion                                                                 |\n|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|\n| Mass                     | Up to approximately 1 tonne (2,200 lb), as demonstrated by Perseverance (2021) |\n| Ballistic coefficient    | Typically 60â€“120 kg/mÂ² for successful missions                            |\n| Diameter of aeroshell    | Up to 4.5 m (15 ft), as in MSL and Perseverance                           |\n| Geometry of aeroshell    | 70Â° spherical cone shell                                                  |\n| Diameter of parachute    | Up to 21.5 m (70 ft), as in Perseverance                                  |\n| Descent                  | Subsonic retropropulsive powered descent (e.g., sky crane)                |\n| Entry                    | Direct hyperbolic entry (from interplanetary trajectory)                  |\n# Communicating with Earth\n\nSince the first successful soft landing by the Soviet Mars 3 mission in 1971, all landers on the surface of Mars that have communicated with Earth have used orbiting spacecraft as [communications satellites](Communications_satellite \"Communications satellite\") for relaying their data to Earth.[](https://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/mars-71.htm) The landers use [UHF](Ultra_high_frequency \"Ultra high frequency\") transmitters to send their data to the orbiters, which then relay the data to Earth using either [X band](X_band \"X band\") or [Ka band](Ka_band \"Ka band\") frequencies. These higher frequencies, along with more powerful transmitters and larger [parabolic reflectors](Parabolic_reflector \"Parabolic reflector\"), permit the orbiters to send the data much faster than the landers could manage transmitting directly to Earth, which conserves valuable time on the [receiving antennas](NASA_Deep_Space_Network \"NASA Deep Space Network\").[12]\n# List of Mars landings\n\nIn the 1970s, several USSR probes unsuccessfully tried to land on Mars. [Mars 3](Mars_3 \"Mars 3\") landed successfully in 1971 but failed soon afterwards. But the American _Viking_ landers made it to the surface and provided several years of images and data. However, the next successful Mars landing was not until 1997, when [Mars Pathfinder](Mars_Pathfinder \"Mars Pathfinder\") landed.[13] In the 21st century there have been several successful landings, but there have also been many crashes.[13]\n\n### Mars probe program\n\nThe first probe intended to be a Mars [impact](Impact_\\(mechanics\\) \"Impact \\(mechanics\\)\") lander was the Soviet _[Mars 1962B](Mars_1962B \"Mars 1962B\")_ , unsuccessfully launched in 1962.[14]\n\nIn 1970 the Soviet Union began the design of _[Mars 4NM](Mars_4NM \"Mars 4NM\")_ and _[Mars 5NM](Mars_5NM \"Mars 5NM\")_ missions with super-heavy uncrewed Martian spacecraft. First was _[Marsokhod](Marsokhod \"Marsokhod\")_ , with a planned date of early 1973, and second was the Mars sample return mission planned for 1975. Both spacecraft were intended to be launched on the [_N1_ rocket](N1_rocket \"N1 rocket\"), but this rocket never flew successfully and the Mars 4NM and Mars 5NM projects were cancelled.[15]\n\nIn 1971 the Soviet Union sent probes _[Mars 2](Mars_2 \"Mars 2\")_ and _[Mars 3](Mars_3 \"Mars 3\")_ , each carrying a lander, as part of the [Mars probe program](Mars_probe_program \"Mars probe program\") M-71. The Mars 2 lander failed to land and impacted Mars. The Mars 3 lander became the first probe to successfully [soft-land](Soft_landing_\\(rocketry\\) \"Soft landing \\(rocketry\\)\") on Mars, but its data-gathering had less success. The lander began transmitting to the Mars 3 orbiter 90 seconds after landing, but after 14.5 seconds, transmission ceased for unknown reasons. The cause of the failure may have been related to the extremely powerful Martian dust storm taking place at the time. These space probes each contained a Mars rover, [PrOP-M](PrOP-M \"PrOP-M\"), although they were never deployed. \n\nIn 1973, the Soviet Union sent two more landers to Mars, _[Mars 6](Mars_6 \"Mars 6\")_ and _[Mars 7](Mars_7 \"Mars 7\")_. The Mars 6 lander transmitted data during descent but failed upon impact. The Mars 7 probe separated prematurely from the carrying vehicle due to a problem in the operation of one of the onboard systems ([attitude control](Spacecraft_attitude_control \"Spacecraft attitude control\") or retro-rockets) and missed the planet by 1,300 km (810 mi). \n\nThe double-launching [_Mars 5M_ (Mars-79)](Mars_5M \"Mars 5M\") sample return mission was planned for 1979, but was cancelled due to complexity and technical problems. \n\n### Viking program\n\nIn 1976 two American [_Viking_ probes](Viking_program \"Viking program\") entered orbit about Mars and each released a [lander module](Lander_\\(spacecraft\\) \"Lander \\(spacecraft\\)\") that made a successful [soft landing](Soft_landing_\\(rocketry\\) \"Soft landing \\(rocketry\\)\") on the planet's surface. They subsequently had the first successful transmission of large volumes of data, including the first color pictures and extensive scientific information. Measured temperatures at the landing sites ranged from 150 to 250 K (âˆ’123 to âˆ’23 Â°C; âˆ’190 to âˆ’10 Â°F), with a variation over a given day of 35 to 50 Â°C (95 to 122 Â°F). Seasonal dust storms, pressure changes, and movement of atmospheric gases between the polar caps were observed. A [biology experiment](Viking_Biological_Experiments \"Viking Biological Experiments\") produced possible evidence of life, but it was not corroborated by other on-board experiments. \n\nWhile searching for a suitable landing spot for _[Viking 2](Viking_2 \"Viking 2\")_ 's lander, the _[Viking 1](Viking_1 \"Viking 1\")_ orbiter photographed the landform that constitutes the so-called \"[Face on Mars](Face_on_Mars \"Face on Mars\")\" on 25 July 1976. \n\nThe Viking program was a descendant of the cancelled [Voyager program](Voyager_program_\\(Mars\\) \"Voyager program \\(Mars\\)\"), whose name was later reused for a pair of outer solar system probes. \n\n### _Mars Pathfinder_\n\n[NASA](NASA \"NASA\")'s _[Mars Pathfinder](Mars_Pathfinder \"Mars Pathfinder\")_ spacecraft, with assistance from the _[Mars Global Surveyor](Mars_Global_Surveyor \"Mars Global Surveyor\")_ orbiter, landed on 4 July 1997. Its landing site was an ancient flood plain in Mars's northern hemisphere called [Ares Vallis](Ares_Vallis \"Ares Vallis\"), which is among the rockiest parts of Mars. It carried a tiny remote-controlled rover called [_Sojourner_](Sojourner_\\(rover\\) \"Sojourner \\(rover\\)\"), the first successful [Mars rover](Mars_rover \"Mars rover\"), that traveled a few meters around the landing site, exploring the conditions and sampling rocks around it. Newspapers around the world carried images of the lander dispatching the rover to explore the surface of Mars in a way never achieved before. \n\nUntil the final data transmission on 27 September 1997, _Mars Pathfinder_ returned 16,500 images from the lander and 550 images from the rover, as well as more than 15 chemical analyses of rocks and soil and extensive data on winds and other weather factors. Findings from the investigations carried out by scientific instruments on both the lander and the rover suggest that in the past Mars has been warm and wet, with liquid water and a thicker atmosphere. The mission website was the most heavily trafficked up to that time. \n\n### Spate of failures\n\n| Mars Spacecraft 1988â€“1999 | Evaluation | Had or was Lander |\n|---------------------------|------------|-------------------|\n| Phobos 1                  | No         | For Phobos        |\n| Phobos 2                  | Yes        | For Phobos        |\n| Mars Observer             | No         | No                |\n| Mars 96                   | No         | Yes               |\n| _Mars Pathfinder_         | Yes        | Yes               |\n| Mars Global Surveyor      | Yes        | No                |\n| Mars Climate Orbiter      | No         | No                |\n| Mars Polar Lander         | No         | Yes               |\n| Deep Space 2              | No         | Yes               |\n| Nozomi                    | No         | No                |\n\n_[Mars 96](Mars_96 \"Mars 96\")_ , an orbiter launched on 16 November 1996 by Russia, failed when the planned second burn of the Block D-2 fourth stage did not occur. Following the success of Global Surveyor and Pathfinder, another spate of failures occurred in 1998 and 1999, with the Japanese [_Nozomi_](Nozomi_\\(spacecraft\\) \"Nozomi \\(spacecraft\\)\") orbiter and NASA's _[Mars Climate Orbiter](Mars_Climate_Orbiter \"Mars Climate Orbiter\")_ , _[Mars Polar Lander](Mars_Polar_Lander \"Mars Polar Lander\")_ , and _[Deep Space 2](Deep_Space_2 \"Deep Space 2\")_ penetrators all suffering various terminal errors. Mars Climate Orbiter is infamous for [Lockheed Martin](Lockheed_Martin \"Lockheed Martin\") engineers mixing up the usage of [U.S. customary units](U.S._customary_units \"U.S. customary units\") with [metric units](Metric_system \"Metric system\"), causing the orbiter to burn up while entering Mars's atmosphere. Out of 5â€“6 NASA missions in the 1990s, only 2 worked: Mars Pathfinder and Mars Global Surveyor, making Mars Pathfinder and its rover the only successful Mars landing in the 1990s. \n\n### Mars Express and _Beagle 2_\n\nOn 2 June 2003, the [European Space Agency](European_Space_Agency \"European Space Agency\")'s _[Mars Express](Mars_Express \"Mars Express\")_ set off from [Baikonur Cosmodrome](Baikonur_Cosmodrome \"Baikonur Cosmodrome\") to Mars. The Mars Express craft consisted of the _[Mars Express Orbiter](Mars_Express_Orbiter \"Mars Express Orbiter\")_ and the lander _[Beagle 2](Beagle_2 \"Beagle 2\")_. Although the landing probe was not designed to move, it carried a digging device and the least massive spectrometer created to date, as well as a range of other devices, on a robotic arm in order to accurately analyse soil beneath the dusty surface. \n\nThe orbiter entered Mars orbit on 25 December 2003, and _Beagle 2_ should have entered Mars's atmosphere the same day. However, attempts to contact the lander failed. Communications attempts continued throughout January, but _Beagle 2_ was declared lost in mid-February, and a joint inquiry was launched by the UK and ESA that blamed principal investigator [Colin Pillinger](Colin_Pillinger \"Colin Pillinger\")'s poor project management. Nevertheless, Mars Express Orbiter confirmed the presence of water ice and carbon dioxide ice at the planet's south pole. NASA had previously confirmed their presence at the north pole of Mars. \n\nSigns of the _Beagle 2_ lander were found in 2013 by the [HiRISE](HiRISE \"HiRISE\") camera on NASA's _[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter](Mars_Reconnaissance_Orbiter \"Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter\")_ , and the _Beagle 2_ 's presence was confirmed in January 2015, several months after Pillinger's death. The lander appears to have successfully landed but not deployed all of its power and communications panels. \n\n### Mars Exploration Rovers\n\nShortly after the launch of Mars Express, NASA sent a pair of twin rovers toward the planet as part of the _[Mars Exploration Rover](Mars_Exploration_Rover \"Mars Exploration Rover\")_ mission. On 10 June 2003, NASA's _[MER-A](MER-A \"MER-A\")_ _(Spirit)_ Mars Exploration Rover was launched. It successfully landed in [Gusev Crater](Gusev_\\(Mars_crater\\) \"Gusev \\(Mars crater\\)\") (believed once to have been a crater lake) on 3 January 2004. It examined rock and soil for evidence of the area's history of water. On 7 July 2003, a second rover, _[MER-B](MER-B \"MER-B\")_ _(Opportunity)_ was launched. It landed on 24 January 2004 in [Meridiani Planum](Meridiani_Planum \"Meridiani Planum\") (where there are large deposits of [hematite](Hematite \"Hematite\"), indicating the presence of past water) to carry out similar geological work. \n\nDespite a temporary loss of communication with the _Spirit_ rover (caused by a file system anomaly[16]) delaying exploration for several days, both rovers eventually began exploring their landing sites. The rover _Opportunity_ landed in a particularly interesting spot, a crater with bedrock outcroppings. In fast succession, mission team members announced on 2 March that data returned from the rover showed that these rocks were once \"drenched in water\", and on 23 March that it was concluded that they were laid down underwater in a salty sea. This represented the first strong direct evidence for liquid water on Mars at some time in the past. \n\nTowards the end of July 2005, it was reported by the _[Sunday Times](The_Sunday_Times_\\(UK\\) \"The Sunday Times \\(UK\\)\")_ that the rovers may have carried the [bacteria](Bacteria \"Bacteria\") _[Bacillus safensis](Bacillus_safensis \"Bacillus safensis\")_ to Mars. According to one NASA microbiologist, this bacteria could survive both the trip and conditions on Mars. Despite efforts to sterilise both landers, neither could be assured to be completely sterile.[17]\n\nHaving been designed for only three-month missions, both rovers lasted much longer than planned. _Spirit_ lost contact with Earth in March 2010, 74 months after commencing exploration. _Opportunity_ , however, continued to carry out surveys of the planet, surpassing 45 km (28 mi) on its odometer by the time communication with it was lost in June 2018, 173 months after it began.[18][19] These rovers have discovered many new things, including [Heat Shield Rock](Heat_Shield_Rock \"Heat Shield Rock\"), the first [meteorite](Meteorite \"Meteorite\") to be discovered on another planet. \n\nHere is some debris from a Mars landing, as viewed by a Rover. This shows the area around a heat shield and resulting shield impact crater. The heat shield was jettisoned during the descent, impacting the surface on its own trajectory, while the spacecraft went on to land the rover.\n\n### _Phoenix_\n\n_[Phoenix](Phoenix_\\(spacecraft\\) \"Phoenix \\(spacecraft\\)\")_ launched on 4 August 2007, and touched down on the northern polar region of Mars on 25 May 2008. It is famous for having been successfully photographed while landing, since this was the first time one spacecraft captured the landing of another spacecraft onto a planet.[20]\n\n### Mars Science Laboratory\n\nThe [Mars Science Laboratory (MSL)](Mars_Science_Laboratory \"Mars Science Laboratory\") (and [Curiosity rover](Curiosity_rover \"Curiosity rover\")), launched in November 2011, landed in a location that is now called \"[Bradbury Landing](Bradbury_Landing \"Bradbury Landing\")\", on [Aeolis Palus](Aeolis_Palus \"Aeolis Palus\"), between [Peace Vallis](Peace_Vallis \"Peace Vallis\") and [Aeolis Mons (\"Mount Sharp\")](Aeolis_Mons \"Aeolis Mons\"), in [Gale Crater](Gale_\\(crater\\) \"Gale \\(crater\\)\") on [Mars](Mars \"Mars\") on 6 August 2012, 05:17 UTC.[21][22] The landing site was in _Quad 51_ (\"Yellowknife\")[23][24][25][26] of _Aeolis Palus_ near the base of _Aeolis Mons_. The landing site[27] was less than 2.4 km (1.5 mi) from the center of the rover's planned target site after a 563,000,000 km (350,000,000 mi) journey.[28] [NASA](NASA \"NASA\") named the landing site \"[Bradbury Landing](Bradbury_Landing \"Bradbury Landing\")\", in honor of author [Ray Bradbury](Ray_Bradbury \"Ray Bradbury\"), on 22 August 2012.[27]\n\n### ExoMars _Schiaparelli_\n\nThe [_Schiaparelli_ lander](Schiaparelli_EDM_lander \"Schiaparelli EDM lander\") was intended to test technology for future soft landings on the surface of Mars as part of the [ExoMars](ExoMars \"ExoMars\") project. It was built in [Italy](Italy \"Italy\") by the [European Space Agency](European_Space_Agency \"European Space Agency\") (ESA) and [Roscosmos](Roscosmos \"Roscosmos\"). It was launched together with the [ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter](ExoMars_Trace_Gas_Orbiter \"ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter\") (TGO) on 14 March 2016 and attempted a landing on 19 October 2016. Telemetry was lost about one minute before the scheduled landing time,[29] but confirmed that most elements of the landing plan, including heat shield operation, parachute deployment, and rocket activation, had been successful.[30] The [Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter](Mars_Reconnaissance_Orbiter \"Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter\") later captured imagery showing what appears to be Schiaparelli's crash site.[31]\n\n### _InSight_\n\nNASA's _[InSight](InSight \"InSight\")_ lander _,_ designed to study seismology and heat flow from the deep interior of Mars, was launched on 5 May 2018. It landed successfully in Mars's [Elysium Planitia](Elysium_Planitia \"Elysium Planitia\") on 26 November 2018.[32]\n\n### Mars 2020 and _Tianwen-1_\n\nNASA's [Mars 2020](Mars_2020 \"Mars 2020\") and [CNSA](China_National_Space_Administration \"China National Space Administration\")'s _[Tianwen-1](Tianwen-1 \"Tianwen-1\")_ were both launched in the July 2020 window. Mars 2020's rover [_Perseverance_](Perseverance_\\(rover\\) \"Perseverance \\(rover\\)\") successfully landed, in a location that is now called \"[Octavia E. Butler Landing](Octavia_E._Butler_Landing \"Octavia E. Butler Landing\")\", in [Jezero Crater](Jezero_\\(crater\\) \"Jezero \\(crater\\)\") on 18 February 2021,[33] [_Ingenuity_ helicopter](Ingenuity_\\(helicopter\\) \"Ingenuity \\(helicopter\\)\") was deployed and took subsequent flights in April.[34] _Tianwen_ -1's lander and [_Zhurong_](Tianwen-1#Zhurong_rover \"Tianwen-1\") rover landed in [Utopia Planitia](Utopia_Planitia \"Utopia Planitia\") on 14 May 2021 with the rover being deployed on 22 May 2021 and dropping a remote selfie camera on 1 June 2021.[35]\n\n### Future missions\n\nThe [ESA](European_Space_Agency \"European Space Agency\")'s _[Rosalind Franklin](Rosalind_Franklin_\\(rover\\) \"Rosalind Franklin \\(rover\\)\")_ rover is planned for launch in 2028 with a new European lander developed by Airbus and would obtain soil samples from up to 2 metres (6 ft 7 in) depth and make an extensive search for [biosignatures](Biosignature \"Biosignature\") and [biomolecules](Biomolecule \"Biomolecule\"). There is an ongoing [Mars Sample Return Mission](Mars_Sample_Return_Mission \"Mars Sample Return Mission\") by ESA and NASA, with sample return projected for 2035â€“2039 following redesigns announced in 2025.[](https://www.nasa.gov/news-release/nasa-exploring-alternative-mars-sample-return-methods/) This mission would be part of the European [Aurora Programme](Aurora_Programme \"Aurora Programme\"). \n\nThe [Indian Space Research Organisation](Indian_Space_Research_Organisation \"Indian Space Research Organisation\") (ISRO)'s Mangalyaan-2 mission, approved in 2025, plans to land a rover and rotorcraft/helicopter around 2031.[](https://www.newindianexpress.com/states/karnataka/2025/Oct/24/90-per-cent-work-on-gaganyaan-mission-completed-isro-chief-narayanan) China plans the Tianwen-3 sample-return mission for launch around 2028, including a landing and ascent vehicle.[](https://english.www.gov.cn/news/202507/23/content_WS68803af3c6d0868f4e8f45d3.html)\n# Landing site identification\n\nLanding site identification for Mars missions involves two primary phases: pre-mission selection based on orbital data and real-time hazard detection and avoidance during entry, descent, and landing (EDL). These processes ensure safe touchdowns in challenging terrain while prioritizing scientific objectives.[](https://marsoweb.nas.nasa.gov/)\n\nPre-mission site selection begins years before launch, using high-resolution imagery and topographic data from orbiters such as NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO). Candidate sites are evaluated for engineering constraints, including low elevation (to allow thicker atmosphere for aerobraking), latitudes between 5Â°N and 5Â°S for sufficient solar power, slopes less than 15 degrees, and few rocks larger than 0.5 meters to avoid damaging the lander or rover. Sites are also chosen for scientific value, such as evidence of past water or habitability. For example, the Perseverance rover's Jezero Crater site was selected in 2017 after workshops evaluating multiple candidates.[](https://science.nasa.gov/resource/landing-sites-under-consideration-for-the-mars-2020-rover/)[](https://mars.nasa.gov/mars2020/mission/spacecraft/rover/landing-site-selection/)\n\nDuring descent, advanced missions employ autonomous systems to identify and avoid hazards in real time. Early landers like Viking relied on pre-selected \"go/no-go\" zones without onboard imaging. However, since the 2010s, technologies like the Hazard Detection and Avoidance (HDA) system have been developed. NASA's Perseverance mission (landed February 2021) used Terrain-Relative Navigation (TRN), which compares descent images from onboard cameras to onboard maps derived from MRO data, enabling precise landing within 100 meters of the target and avoiding slopes or boulders. China's Tianwen-1 mission (landed May 2021) also incorporated similar autonomous capabilities for its Zhurong rover in Utopia Planitia. As of October 2025, no additional soft landings have occurred, but future missions like NASA's Mars Sample Return plan to leverage enhanced precision landing technologies.[](https://www-robotics.jpl.nasa.gov/media/documents/aejJGCD2002.pdf)[](https://www.nasa.gov/directorates/stmd/nasa-tests-new-ways-to-stick-the-landing-in-challenging-terrain/)\n# Twinned locations to Mars Landing sites on Earth\n\nIn the run-up to NASAâ€™s Mars 2020 landing, former planetary scientist and film-maker [Christopher Riley](Christopher_Riley \"Christopher Riley\") mapped the locations of all eight of NASA's successful Mars landing sites onto their equivalent spots on Earth, in terms of latitudes and longitudes; presenting pairs of photographs from each twinned interplanetary location on Earth and Mars to draw attention to climate change.[38] Following the successful landing of NASA's [Perseverance Rover](Perseverance_\\(rover\\) \"Perseverance \\(rover\\)\") on February 18, 2021, Riley called for volunteers to travel to and photograph its twinned Earth location in Andegaon Wadi, Sawali, in the central Indian state of [Maharashtra](Maharashtra \"Maharashtra\") (18.445Â°N, 77.451Â°E).[39][40][41] Eventually [BBC World Service](BBC_World_Service \"BBC World Service\") radio programme [Digital Planet](Digital_Planet \"Digital Planet\") listener Gowri Abhiram, from [Hyderabad](Hyderabad \"Hyderabad\") took up the challenge, and travelled there on the 22nd January 2022, becoming the first person to knowingly reach a spot on Earth that matches the latitude and longitude of a robotic presence on the surface of another world.[42] China's Tianwen-1 landing site maps onto an area in Southern China, 40 kilometres Southwest of [Guilin](Guilin \"Guilin\") and is yet to be photographed for the project.[40]"])</script><script nonce="NzIzZjI4MWItYmRjOS00NTJjLTg3OTYtY2VkMDhhY2VmY2Q3">self.__next_f.push([1,"8:[\"$\",\"$L13\",null,{\"state\":{\"mutations\":[],\"queries\":[{\"dehydratedAt\":1761883054584,\"state\":{\"data\":{\"page\":{\"citations\":[{\"id\":\"1\",\"title\":\"** mars.nasa.gov. Retrieved 17 March 2017.\",\"url\":\"https://sandilands.info/sgordon/communications-with-mars-curiosity\",\"favicon\":\"\"},{\"id\":\"13\",\"title\":\"_**a**_ _**b**_ Howell, Elizabeth; Stein, Vicky (1 March 2022). [\\\"A Brief History of Mars Missions\\\"](https://www.space.com/13558-historic-mars-missions.html). _Space.com_.\",\"description\":\"13. ^ _**a**_ _**b**_ Howell, Elizabeth; Stein, Vicky (1 March 2022). [\\\"From Mars to Earth\\\"](https://christopher-riley.medium.com/from-mars-to-earth-18ae2597e3fe). Medium. Retrieved 22 April 2022.\",\"description\":\"42. **^** Riley, Christopher (13 February 2021). [\\\"From Mars to Earth\\\"](https://christopher-riley.medium.com/from-mars-to-earth-18ae2597e3fe). Medium. Retrieved 22 April 2022.\",\"url\":\"https://christopher-riley.medium.com/from-mars-to-earth-18ae2597e3fe\",\"favicon\":\"\"}],\"images\":[],\"fixedIssues\":[{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Quantitative/Units Error\",\"problematicText\":\"Of multiple attempted Mars landings by robotic, uncrewed spacecraft, ten have had successful soft landings.\",\"explanation\":\"The stated number \\\"ten\\\" is incorrect; there have been eleven successful soft landings, including Mars 3, the two Vikings, Pathfinder, the two MERs, Phoenix, Curiosity, InSight, Perseverance, and Tianwen-1/Zhurong. This misstates the historical record of achievements.\",\"fixedText\":\"Change \\\"ten\\\" to \\\"eleven\\\".\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://www.planetary.org/space-missions/every-mars-mission)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Quantitative/Units Error\",\"problematicText\":\"Soviet Mars 3, which landed in 1971, was the first successful Mars landing, though the spacecraft failed after 110 seconds on the surface.\",\"explanation\":\"The transmission duration after landing was approximately 14.5 seconds, not 110 seconds. This is a factual inaccuracy in a key historical detail.\",\"fixedText\":\"Correct to \\\"after approximately 15 seconds of transmission\\\".\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars_3)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Internal Contradiction\",\"problematicText\":\"Soviet Mars 3, which landed in 1971, was the first successful Mars landing... Of multiple attempted Mars landings... ten have had successful soft landings.\",\"explanation\":\"By designating Mars 3 as the first successful soft landing, the total count must include it, resulting in at least eleven, not ten. This creates inconsistency within the section.\",\"fixedText\":\"Adjust the total count to eleven to align with inclusion of Mars 3.\",\"evidenceSource\":\"Existing ref #1\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Missing Information\",\"problematicText\":\"As of 2023, the Soviet Union, United States, and China have conducted Mars landings successfully.\",\"explanation\":\"The date is outdated given the current date of October 2025; no new landings have occurred, but updating ensures timeliness. Additionally, the ESA/UK's Beagle 2 achieved a successful soft landing (confirmed 2015), though mission failed, warranting mention for completeness.\",\"fixedText\":\"Update to \\\"As of 2025\\\" and add mention of ESA's Beagle 2 as a successful landing despite operational failure.\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beagle_2)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Timeliness/Currency\",\"problematicText\":\"For landers that are even meters (26 feet) in diameter.\",\"explanation\":\"The use of present tense \\\"are developing\\\" implies ongoing active development of the LDSD as of the current date (2025), but the project completed its primary test flights in 2014 and 2015 with no documented further development or testing since then, rendering the claim outdated and potentially misleading about current technology status for Mars landings.\",\"fixedText\":\"Revise to past tense: \\\"engineers developed\\\" or specify the timeframe (e.g., \\\"In the 2010s, engineers tested...\\\"), and note that the technology was intended for future heavier payloads but has not been implemented in missions as of 2025.\",\"evidenceSource\":\"Web search results confirming last LDSD tests in 2015 and no post-2015 updates on NASA sites or authoritative sources.\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Source/Citation Mismatch\",\"problematicText\":\"It would have to be accompanied by a proportionately larger Return or human landings, which would provide temporal context up to 2025.\",\"fixedText\":\"Add a sentence noting that while LDSD testing informed designs, current efforts focus on [brief example, from searches on Mars human mission EDL).\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Quantitative/Units Error\",\"problematicText\":\"Mass | Less than 0.6 tonnes (1,300 lb)\",\"explanation\":\"The stated mass limit of less than 0.6 tonnes does not reflect demonstrated capabilities; NASA's Perseverance rover (Mars 2020) achieved a successful soft landing with a rover mass of 1.025 tonnes in 2021, exceeding this limit by over 70%. This error misrepresents current EDL performance and could mislead on payload scalability for future missions.\",\"fixedText\":\"Update the mass criterion to \\\"Up to approximately 1 tonne (2,200 lb), as demonstrated by recent missions like Perseverance (2021)\\\" and cite authoritative NASA sources.\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perseverance_(rover)) ; [](https://www.nasa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/iparch12-wp-mars-edl.pdf?emrc=82c2a9)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Quantitative/Units Error\",\"problematicText\":\"Ballistic coefficient | Less than 35 kg/m2 (7.2 lb/sq ft)\",\"explanation\":\"The ballistic coefficient limit of less than 35 kg/mÂ² is incorrect for current successful missions; Viking-era was ~60 kg/mÂ², MSL (Curiosity) ~117 kg/mÂ², and Perseverance similar (~120 kg/mÂ²). Lower values are for conceptual low-BC designs, not standard; this understates actual capabilities and violates dimensional consistency for aerodynamic deceleration in Mars' thin atmosphere.\",\"fixedText\":\"Revise to \\\"Typically 60â€“120 kg/mÂ² for successful missions, with higher values requiring advanced guidance\\\" and add citations.\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://ntrs.nasa.gov/api/citations/20090007730/downloads/20090007730.pdf) ; [](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/392508651_Aerodynamic_Study_of_Successful_Mars_Entry_Vehicles)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Source/Citation Mismatch\",\"problematicText\":\"Some of the criteria for a lander performing a successful soft-landing using current technology are as follows:[11][8]\",\"explanation\":\"Ref [11] (2018 arXiv) proposes a novel conceptual EDL architecture for future large-scale landings, not describing \\\"current technology\\\" limits. Ref [8] (2007) predates MSL (2012) and Perseverance (2021), which exceeded its projected challenges (e.g., 0.8 t mass). This mismatches sources to claims, presenting outdated/proposed specs as current.\",\"fixedText\":\"Rephrase introductory sentence to specify \\\"criteria based on heritage designs from the 2000s\\\" or update table with post-2021 data; retain [8] if applicable, replace [11] with new sources for current capabilities.\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://arxiv.org/abs/1809.00062) ; [](https://doi.org/10.2514/1.25116)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Timeliness/Currency\",\"problematicText\":\"[Entire table under \\\"using current technology\\\"]\",\"explanation\":\"The table reflects pre-2012 capabilities (e.g., Viking-era limits) without updates for advancements in MSL (2012, 0.9 t) and Perseverance (2021, 1 t; 4.5 m aeroshell; 21.5 m parachute). As of 2025, no new landings, but documented capabilities exceed table values, making \\\"current\\\" claims outdated and potentially misleading for mission planning.\",\"fixedText\":\"Add \\\"as demonstrated up to 2021\\\" qualifier; update values for mass (1 t), aeroshell (4.5 m), parachute (21.5 m), descent (subsonic retropropulsion via sky crane), and entry (direct hyperbolic, not orbital).\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://www.nasa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/iparch12-wp-mars-edl.pdf?emrc=82c2a9) ; [](https://ntrs.nasa.gov/api/citations/20210024480/downloads/Mars2020_Flight_Mechanics_Simulation_Paper_v3.pdf)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Missing Information\",\"problematicText\":\"[No specific text; overall section]\",\"explanation\":\"The section lacks mention of key advancements post-InSight (2018), such as the sky crane system enabling \u003e1 t landings in MSL/Perseverance, and ongoing developments like supersonic retropropulsion (SRP) tests for scaling to human missions (20+ t). This creates a knowledge gap on recent temporal context and scope for EDL evolution as of 2025.\",\"fixedText\":\"Add a sentence or table note: \\\"Recent missions like Perseverance (2021) have demonstrated up to 1 t landed mass using sky crane and guided entry, paving the way for future SRP for heavier payloads.\\\"\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://www.nasa.gov/entry-descent-and-landing/) ; [](https://www.universetoday.com/articles/the-new-mars-landing-approach-how-well-land-large-payloads-on-the-red-planet)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Source/Citation Mismatch\",\"problematicText\":\"\\\"Beginning with the Viking program,[a] all landers on the surface of Mars have used orbiting spacecraft as [communications satellites]\\\"\",\"explanation\":\"The claim inaccurately states that the practice began with the Viking program in 1976, but the first successful Mars landing was the Soviet Mars 3 in 1971, which used its accompanying orbiter to relay data from the lander. The Eridania basin site is from older proposals and not confirmed in recent sources.\",\"fixedText\":\"Update to: \\\"The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO)'s Mangalyaan-2 mission, approved in 2025, plans to land a rover and rotorcraft/helicopter around 2031.\\\" Remove specific site unless confirmed; replace ref [36] with new citation.\",\"evidenceSource\":\"[](https://www.newindianexpress.com/states/karnataka/2025/Oct/24/90-per-cent-work-on-gaganyaan-mission-completed-isro-chief-narayanan)\"},{\"criticality\":\"Critical\",\"issueType\":\"Missing Information\",\"problematicText\":\"[Entire Future missions subsection]\",\"explanation\":\"Missing recent developments as of October 2025, including China's Tianwen-3 Mars sample-return mission planned for launch in 2028, which would be China's second landing attempt.
